Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of Engineering testbed: Universal chip scale photonic testing instrument (UCPTI)

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop a state-of-the-art photonic chip-scale probing solution for integrated Si-photonics testing and to enable new multidisciplinary collaborative projects in nano-photonics and opto-electronics. The approach exploits a universal electronic-photonic probing station that integrates electrical, optical far-field, and optical near-field probes for electrical and optical interfacing to integrated circuits and to individual elements within such circuits, together with a full set of external optical and electronic instrumentation to provide an affordable, zero-capital-investment testing capability for Research and Development by academic, industry and government laboratories.

The intellectual merit of this versatile and user friendly Si-Photonics testing instrument includes basic research to identify new phenomena, inventing new photonic technology and creating new applications, as well as providing tremendous benefit to small businesses, various research institutions and government laboratories in their product development efforts. Moreover, it can serve as a testbed for development and reduction to practice of new approaches for efficiently probing and testing Si-photonic chips, gradually evolving to become industry standards.

The broader impact of the instrument spans multiple fields, including information systems, high speed electronics and photonics, and future computer science and engineering to create wealth for 21st century economy by advancing integration of nanoscale photonic, electronic and biomedical science and technology. It will provide service to industry in Southern California and play a significant role in the education and development of human resources in science and engineering at the graduate and undergraduate levels helping to train future engineers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chip-scale integrated photonics technology may revolutionize our economy to become the backbone of next generation chip level solutions for information technologies, healthcare, and defense technologies.  To meet the challenge in probing, characterization and testing of the integrated photonics consistent with their corresponding applications, we developed a state-of-the-art Photonic Chip-scale Testing Facility (CPTF) for characterization of various nanophotonic materials, devices and integrated circuits enabling new collaborative projects within and outside the University of California, San Diego (UCSD).  In collaboration with industry (e.g., Keysight Technologies, Oracle, Google, IBM, Qualcomm, Luxtera, Kotura, etc.) we established probing and testing capabilities and unique tools to measure the electrical/optical response of photonic devices and circuits at high speed. The facility equipment is highly integrated due to an open source cross-platform scripting framework and device drivers created by UCSD to serve the facility users as well as the broader nanophotonics community.  CPTF is a recharge facility which is part of Qualcomm Institute at UCSD, where it is maintained and operated. The facility is connected to the data center testing system developed as part of NSF ERC-Center for Integrated Access Networks (CIAN), enabling real time testing of developed photonic devices and circuits in a realistic system application environment. The facility serves local researchers and industry by making equipment with a prohibitively high purchase cost easily accessible. It is available to UCSD faculty and non-UCSD academic institutions, government, defense, and industry collaborators and users. The CPTF tools also assist local industry to perform prototyping of future products, thus helping to advance local economy as well as small businesses in other states. With our participation in the newly established American Institute for Manufacturing Integrated Photonics (AIM Photonics), the CPTF will bring unique testing capabilities to advance United States as a worldwide leader in photonics manufacturing.  The established CPTF also became one of the key nanophotonics research capabilities in the newly established UCSD hub within the NSF’s National Nanotechnology Coordinated Infrastructure (NNCI).  The CPTF plays a key role in education at graduate and undergraduate levels and Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU).
